revision.text:
'''Abbey''' is a given name. It is the given name of: *[[Abbey Bartlet]], a fictional character played by Stockard Channing on the television serial drama, The West Wing *[[Abbey Clancy]] (born 1986), English lingerie and catwalk model *[[Abbey Lee Kershaw]] (born 1987), Australian fashion model *[[Abbey Lincoln]] (1930–2010), African-American jazz vocalist
{{given name}}

{{expand language|topic=|langcode=fr|otherarticle=|date=November 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2017}} {{Infobox military person | name = Adnan Abu Walid al-Sahrawi | birth_name = Lehbib Ould Ali Ould Said Ould Yumani | birth_date = 1973 or 1979 | birth_place = [[Laayoune]], [[Western Sahara]] | allegiance = [[Polisario Front]]
[[Movement for Oneness and Jihad in West Africa|MUJAO]] (2011–2013)
[[Al-Mourabitoun (militant group)|Al-Mourabitoun]] (2013–2015)
[[Islamic State in the Greater Sahara]] (2015–present) }} '''Lehbib Ould Ali Ould Said Ould Yumani''', known as '''Adnan Abu Walid al-Sahrawi''', is an [[Sahrawi people|Sahrawi]] Islamic militant and leader of the [[Islamic State in the Greater Sahara]]. == History == al-Sahrawi was born in [[Laayoune]], [[Western Sahara]] into part of a wealthy trading family that fled the city for [[refugee camp]]s in [[Algeria]].{{cite web|last1=Dilanian|first1=Ken|last2=Kube|first2=Courtney|last3=Bishop|first3=Mac William|title=U.S. Soldiers in Niger Were Pursuing ISIS Recruiter When Ambushed|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/news/africa/u-s-soldiers-niger-were-pursuing-isis-recruiter-when-ambushed-n813746|publisher=NBC News|accessdate=28 November 2017|date=24 October 2017}}{{cite web|last1=Guichaoua|first1=Yvan|last2=Lebovich|first2=Andrew|title=America's options in Niger: join forces to reduce tensions, or fan the flames|url=https://theconversation.com/americas-options-in-niger-join-forces-to-reduce-tensions-or-fan-the-flames-86655|publisher=''The Conversation''|accessdate=28 November 2017|date=2 November 2017}} He joined the [[Polisario Front]] and received military training, but demobilised amid promises of a [[United Nations]] referendum on the status of the Western Sahara. A former commander in [[al-Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb]], he was later part of the group that founded the [[Movement for Oneness and Jihad in West Africa]] in October 2011. While part of MUJWA/MUJAO, he was one of its most senior leaders, serving on its shura council and communicating with international media as MUJWA’s spokesman. By 2013, he was calling himself the leader of an organisation named the Mujahideen Shura Council in [[Gao]], [[Mali]]. After MUJAO merged with [[Mokhtar Belmokhtar]]'s Al-Mulathameen group in August 2013 to form [[Al-Mourabitoun (militant group)|Al-Mourabitoun]], he was an important leader in Al-Murabitoun, later becoming its overall head.{{cite web|url=https://jamestown.org/brief/may-2015-briefs/|title=May 2015 Briefs|website=Jamestown|accessdate=2017-10-26}} On May 13, 2015, Abu Walid declared his allegiance to [[Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi]], leader of the [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant]] and formed [[Islamic State in the Greater Sahara]]. Not all of Murabitoun accepted the move, with [[Mokhtar Belmokhtar]] denying that al-Murabitoun had pledged to Baghdadi, causing a split in the group. More than a year and a half later the allegiance was publicly accepted by IS's Amaq news agency.{{cite web|url=https://www.longwarjournal.org/archives/2016/10/islamic-state-recognizes-oath-of-allegiance-from-jihadists-in-west-africa.php|title=Islamic State recognizes oath of allegiance from jihadists in Mali | FDD's Long War Journal|website=longwarjournal.org|accessdate=2017-10-26}} In May 2016, he was reported to have issued threats against the Moroccan government.{{cite web|url=https://www.longwarjournal.org/archives/2016/05/report-head-of-the-islamic-states-sahara-branch-threatens-morocco.php|title=Report: Head of the Islamic State's Sahara branch threatens Morocco | FDD's Long War Journal|website=longwarjournal.org|accessdate=2017-10-26}} In June 2017, al-Sahrawi accused the Imghad and [[Idaksahak]] communities of defending Niger and France and threatened retaliation against them.{{cite web|title=Jihadist leader Al-Sahraoui accuses and threatens two communities in Mali|url=http://www.rfi.fr/afrique/20170627-chef-jihadiste-al-sahraoui-accuse-menace-communautes-mali-imghad-idaksahak|publisher=RFI|accessdate=28 November 2017|language=French|date=28 June 2017}} == Personal life == He is said to have married a [[Fulani]] woman from the village of Bouratam in 2016. == References == {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Al-Sahrawi, Adnan Abu Walid}} [[Category:1970s births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant members]] [[Category:Sahrawi people]] [[Category:People from Laayoune]] [[Category:Sahrawi rebels]]

{{Infobox comedian |name=Asperger’s Are Us |image =Asperger's Are Us.jpg |caption =From left, Ethan Finlan, Noah Britton, New Michael Ingemi, and Jack Hanke |active=2010-2018 |genre =[[Satire]], [[surreal humour]], [[pun]]s |Current_members =Tripp Carey (former member)
[[Ethan Finlan]]
[[Jack Hanke]]
[[The Best Thing Ever|Noah Britton]]
[[New Michael Ingemi]] |website =[http://www.facebook.com/aspergersareus Official Facebook page] }} '''Asperger’s Are Us''' was an American comedy team. They are known for being the first comedy troupe formed by people with [[Asperger syndrome]].{{Cite web|last=|first=|authorlink=|title=Asperger’s Are Us|work=Facebook.com|publisher=Asperger’s Are Us|year=2010|url=http://www.facebook.com/aspergersareus/info|accessdate=2017-06-30}} ==Biography== Asperger’s Are Us formed on the [[North Shore (Massachusetts)|North Shore of Massachusetts]] in the summer of 2010 after New Michael Ingemi, Jack Hanke, and Ethan Finlan graduated from a summer camp where Noah Britton was their counselor.{{Cite news|last=Weintraub|first=Karen|title=Asperger’s Are Us comedy troupe plays off their disability|newspaper=USA Today|location=McLean, Va.|pages=|publisher=Gannett Company|date=2012-04-13|url=https://www.usatoday.com/news/health/wellness/story/2012-04-12/Aspergers-Are-Us-comedy-troupe/54256940/1|accessdate=2017-06-30}} They have performed over 100 original sketch comedy shows in nine countries {{Cite web|last=|first=|authorlink=|title=Asperger’s Are Us|work=|publisher=Asperger’s Are Us|year=|url=http://www.geocities.ws/aspergersareus|accessdate=2017-10-23}} and have been interviewed several times by both local and national press.{{Cite web|last=Pfeiffer|first=Sacha|authorlink=|title=‘Asperger’s Are Us’ Adds Laughter To A Serious Condition|work=All Things Considered|publisher=Boston University|year=2011|url=http://www.wbur.org/2011/06/23/aspbergers-syndrome-comedy|accessdate=2017-06-30}}{{Cite web|last= |first= |authorlink= |title=Asperger’s sketch troupe provides an atypical take on comedy |work=Boston Metro |publisher=Echo Media |year= |url=http://www.metro.us/boston/entertainment/article/1140149--asperger-s-sketch-troupe-provides-an-atypical-take-on-comedy |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120908062812/http://www.metro.us/boston/entertainment/article/1140149--asperger-s-sketch-troupe-provides-an-atypical-take-on-comedy |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2012-09-08 |accessdate=2012-05-25 }}{{Cite news|last=Smith|first=Jada F.|title=Asperger’s Are Us Comedy Troupe Jokes About Everything but That|newspaper=The New York Times|location=New York|pages=|publisher=Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, Jr.|date=2016-07-15|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/07/16/arts/television/aspergers-are-us-comedy-troupe-jokes-about-everything-but-that.html|accessdate=2017-06-30}} A [[Duplass Brothers Productions]] documentary about the troupe was released on [[Netflix]] in late 2016.{{Cite web|last=Evans|first=Greg|authorlink=|title=Netflix Nabs ‘Asperger’s Are Us’ Documentary At SXSW|work=Deadline Hollywood|publisher=Penske Business Media, LLC|year=2016|url=https://deadline.com/2016/03/netflix-aspergers-are-us-sxsw-1201719346/|accessdate=2017-06-30}} Asperger's Are Us disbanded in 2018.{{Cite web|last=Us|first=Asperger's Are|authorlink=|title=Cover photo|work=Facebook.com|publisher=Facebook.com|year=2018|url=https://www.facebook.com/aspergersareus/|accessdate=2018-05-28}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *Official website [http://www.aspergersareus.com/] [[Category:American comedy troupes]] [[Category:People with Asperger syndrome]] [[Category:Sketch comedy troupes]]

[[File:Benzhu Sanxing, Dali, Yunnan.jpg|thumb|300px|The [[Sanxing (deities)|Sanxing]] (Three Star Gods) at a Benzhu temple on Jinsuo Island, in [[Dali Bai Autonomous Prefecture|Dali]], [[Yunnan]].]] '''Benzhuism''' ({{zh|c=本主教|p=Běnzhǔjiào|l=religion of the patrons}}) is the [[indigenous religion]] of the [[Bai people]], an ethnic group of [[Yunnan]], [[China]]. It consists in the worship of the ''ngel zex'', the [[Bai language|Bai]] word for "patrons" or "lords", rendered as ''benzhu'' (本主) in [[Chinese language|Chinese]], that are local gods and [[progenitor|deified ancestors]] of the Bai people. It is very similar to common [[Chinese folk religion|Chinese religion]].
While many of the Bai are [[Buddhists]], the local government of China has recently helped the revival of the Benzhu [[ethnic religion]], for example through the promotion of the Gwer Sa La festival.<ref>Liang Yongjia, 2013.</ref>
==The patrons== ===Local lords and ancestors=== The ''benzhu'' are mainly [[deification|deified]] ancestors, "patrons" or "lords" of the local communities. Every Bai village has its own pantheon of gods which has formed throughout its existence, incorporating its history in deifying virtuous leaders, warriors, and [[hero]]es.<ref name="culturalchina"> ''Cultural China'', [http://traditions.cultural-china.com/en/216Traditions9978.html The Benzhu religion of the Bai]. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131103070312/http://traditions.cultural-china.com/en/216Traditions9978.html |date=November 3, 2013 }}</ref> These deities, who are tied to the immediate surroundings, protect the people against sickness and violence, foster local economy, and grant prosperity.<ref name="culturalchina"/>
Generally, one village enshrines one benzhu, and there are also cases of multiple villages consecrated to the same benzhu. In every village around [[Erhai Lake]] the local people have developed a peculiar mythology about their local lord, differing from that of neighboring villages.<ref name="culturalchina"/> This tradition is similar to that of the [[City God (China)|City God Temple]] of Chinese religion.<ref name="culturalchina"/>
===Gods of nature=== Other ''benzhu'' are gods of the generation of the local place.<ref name="culturalchina"/> These include the God of the Mountain, the God of the Crops, the God of the Hunt, the [[Dragon King]] or the Mother Goddess of the Dragon King.<ref name="culturalchina"/>
==Features== ===Benzhu festivals=== Benzhu Festivals in [[Dali City]] take place according to the [[Chinese calendar|lunar calendar]], after [[Chinese New Year]]. During festivals, the benzhu shrine are taken from the temples and carried through the towns to a different location where they stay for a number of days. The villagers follow the gods to the designated place burning incense and worshiping with food and money.
===Psychology and shamanism=== The Bai believe that the soul does not die with the body, but it can go to the "Kingdom of the Shades" helped by complex ritual ceremonies performed by the living community.<ref name="culturalchina"/> Angry spirits can cause illness, but local gods can protect people against them. Illnesses are caused by the possession of evil spirits and they can be treated by female [[shaman]]s.<ref name="culturalchina"/>
===Cult of the white stones=== The Nama branch of the Bai, residing near the [[Mekong River]], preserves a cult of the white stones common to the ethnic groups descended from the [[Qiang people]].<ref name="culturalchina"/> Some believe they represent the bones of the ancestors, others that they are a representation of the Fire God, a deity worshipped around [[China]].<ref name="culturalchina"/>
==See also== * [[Bimoism]] * [[Chinese folk religion]] * [[Confucianism]] * [[Dongbaism]] * [[Taoism]] * [[Zhuang folk religion]]
==Bibliography== <!-- * Liang Yongjia. "[https://muse.jhu.edu/article/520437/summary Superscription without Encompassment: Turning Gwer Sa La Festival into Intangible Cultural Heritage]". In: ''Religious Revival in Ethnic Areas of China''. Asia Research Institute, National University of Singapore, 2011. This seems to be the same as below-->
* Liang Yongjia. "[https://muse.jhu.edu/article/520437/summary Turning Gwer Sa La Festival into Intangible Cultural Heritage: State Superscription of Popular Religion in Southwest China]". In: '' China: An International Journal''. Volume 11, Number 2, August 2013. pp. 58-75
==References== <references />
==External links== * [http://www.asiaculturaltravel.co.uk/benzhuism-of-bai-ethnic-minority/ Benzhuism of the Bai Ethnic Minority], China & Asia Cultural Travel, TanSuo Cultural Travel Solution Ltd.
{{Religion topics}}
[[Category:Bai people]] [[Category:Culture in Yunnan]] [[Category:East Asian religions]] [[Category:Religion in China]] [[Category:Shamanism in China]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox building | name = Big Tex | image = Big_Tex_2013.jpg | caption = The newly reconstructed Big Tex at his unveiling, September 27, 2013. | building_type = | architectural_style = | structural_system = | location = [[Fair Park]] in [[Dallas]] | coordinates = {{coord|32.7797|-96.7644|type:landmark_scale:10000_region:US|display=inline,title}} | map_type = Texas | completion_date = 2013 (1949-2012, original) | height = 55 feet | floor_count = | main_contractor = | architect = | structural_engineer = | services_engineer = | civil_engineer = | other_designers = | quantity_surveyor = | awards = }}
'''Big Tex''' is a 55-foot (16.75m) tall statue and marketing icon of the annual [[State Fair of Texas]] held at [[Fair Park]] in [[Dallas]], [[Texas]]. The figure has become a cultural icon of Dallas and Texas. Since 1952 Big Tex has served as a cultural ambassador to visitors, and the statue's prime location in the fairgrounds serves as a traditional meeting point.
On October 19, 2012, the last weekend of the 2012 State Fair of Texas, Big Tex was destroyed by an electrical fire that started in the right boot and worked its way up the structure, first becoming visible from the neck area. After the fire, a new Big Tex was created by SRO Associates and Texas Scenic Co. This rendition made its first public appearance on September 26, 2013.<ref name="dallasnews.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.dallasnews.com/entertainment/state-fair-of-texas/headlines/20130926-resurrection-of-big-tex-called-for-engineering-skill-secrecy.ece|title=Resurrection of Big Tex called for engineering skill, secrecy|work=dallasnews.com|accessdate=21 July 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dallasnews.com/entertainment/state-fair-of-texas/headlines/20130927-throughout-the-summer-big-tex-took-shape.ece|title=Throughout the summer, Big Tex took shape|work=dallasnews.com|accessdate=21 July 2015}}</ref>
==History== [[File:Big-tex-1956.jpg|left|200px|thumb|Big Tex, 1956]]
===Origins=== [[Kerens, Texas]] is known as the "Birthplace of Big Tex", although his original incarnation was as a 49-foot (15 m) tall [[Santa Claus]] constructed from [[iron]] [[Casing (borehole)|drill casing]], [[papier mache]], and unraveled rope in 1949.<ref name="ci.kerens">{{cite web|url=http://ci.kerens.tx.us/index.php?id=mteznzm1odmxnq5|title=City of Kerens, Texas|work=kerens.tx.us|accessdate=21 July 2015}}</ref> The statue was an idea of Howell Brister, manager of the Chamber of Commerce, to encourage holiday sales in the town, and the "World's Largest Santa Claus" (a claim later disputed) stood over Colket Avenue for two holiday seasons — drawing press attention from as far away as Iran and Australia.<ref name="BigTex_a">"Big Tex ready for 60th." Dallas Morning News, The (TX) 28 Sep. 2012, 1, BRIEFING: 09. NewsBank. Web. 19 Oct. 2012.</ref><ref name="bigtex">{{cite web |url=http://www.bigtex.com/sft/AboutUs/BigTex.asp |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-10-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121022170914/http://www.bigtex.com/sft/AboutUs/BigTex.asp |archivedate=2012-10-22 |df= }}</ref><ref>"Big D." Dallas Morning News. 12-17-1952</ref> Modeled after Kerens residents Ottis Franklin Spurlock and Hardy Mayo, the figure was built by members of the community who welded the frame, fabricated the body and sewed the clothing.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://lubbockonline.com/texas/2011-12-12/recalling-history-big-tex#.UIGSS2mMXV4|title=Recalling the history of Big Tex|work=Lubbock Online - Lubbock Avalanche-Journal|accessdate=21 July 2015}}</ref>
After two seasons the excitement over the statue faded, and Kerens offered it up for sale. In 1951, State Fair president [[R. L. Thornton]] purchased Santa's components for $750 and had artist Jack Bridges transform them into a [[cowboy]], giving birth to "Big Tex".
===1952 to 2012=== Big Tex made his debut at the 1952 fair, a 52-foot cowboy dressed in denim jeans and a plaid shirt donated by the H. D. Lee Company of Shawnee Mission, Kansas.<ref name="big tex" /> Artist Jack Bridges used a photograph of his own face, a photograph of rancher Doc Simmons and a photograph of Will Rogers to create the new look.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.yesterdayusa.com/big_tex_fact_page.htm|title=BIG TEX FACT PAGE|work=yesterdayusa.com|accessdate=21 July 2015}}</ref> After the fair, his appearance was slightly altered to straighten his nose and correct an odd wink. It was in 1953 that Big Tex also began speaking. Using a custom-built recipromotor and a 75-watt speaker system housed in the figure's head, Jack Bridges devised a way to create the illusion of natural speech with a swinging jaw.<ref>"The Tallest Talkin' Texan is Texas' Tallest Talker." Dallas Morning News. 10-11-1953.</ref> Tex also attended a convention in [[Minneapolis]] that year with the Dallas [[Jaycees]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bigtex.com/sft/guestinfo/documents/BigTex101.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-10-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131013201843/http://www.bigtex.com/sft/guestinfo/documents/BigTex101.pdf |archivedate=2013-10-13 |df= }}</ref>
In 1955 Big Tex received his first new change of clothes, again fabricated by the H. D. Lee Company.<ref>"Fair's Big 'Tex' to Get New Duds." Dallas Morning News. 09-26-1955</ref> After that year's fair, he traveled to West Texas to participate in [[Abilene Christian University|Abilene Christian College]]'s 50th annual homecoming celebration.<ref>"Big Tex Goes to College." Dallas Morning News. 11-01-1955</ref> A 12-foot-tall, 19-foot long plastic model of a Hereford steer (called "The Champ") accompanied Big Tex for the 1956 fair, but Big Tex was primarily displayed alone. During the 1950s Big Tex underwent further re-design, replacing the papier mache "skin" with fiberglass. The original head was put into storage and later sold at auction in 1993 to a Dallas collector.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chron.com/communityblogs/atmosphere/article/Archive-Head-of-Big-Tex-goes-for-big-bucks-at-3964277.php|title=Archive: Head of Big Tex goes for big bucks at auction|work=Houston Chronicle|accessdate=21 July 2015}}</ref>
[[File:Big Tex for State Fair of Texas 2006.jpg|200px|thumb|Big Tex, 2006]]
The State Fair of Texas announced the construction of a permanent, year-round statue of Big Tex in 1961, but the figure remained a seasonal feature appearing only during the fair.<ref>"Tex to Get Permanent Fair Home." Dallas Morning News. 09-21-1961.</ref> Instead, the Big Tex Circle display area was redesigned in 1966 with a larger mound.<ref>"Big Tex Gets Buildup." Dallas Morning News. 08-29-1966</ref>
Big Tex traveled to his hometown of Kerens, Texas in 1981 to help celebrate the 100th anniversary of the city.<ref name="ci.kerens" /> The figure continued to travel to various promotional events until the mid-1980s.
In 1997, Big Tex was given a skeletal makeover consisting of 4,200 feet of steel rods weighing 6,000 pounds. The new skeleton adjusted the posture and allowed for a new hand that waved to passersby, but kept the original head.<ref>Floyd, Jacquielynn. "A REFINED COWBOY - Body building has given Big Tex a picturesque physique." Dallas Morning News, The (TX) 23 Sep. 1997, ARLINGTON MORNING NEWS, NEWS ARLINGTON: 10A. NewsBank. Web. 19 Oct. 2012.</ref> Three years later his neck was animated, allowing it to turn; his mechanical mouth was also upgraded with a new system.<ref>Horner, Kim. "A turning point - State Fair will be a pivotal moment for Big Tex and new swiveling head." The Dallas Morning News 15 Sep. 2000, THIRD, NEWS: 1A. NewsBank. Web. 19 Oct. 2012.</ref>
Big Tex celebrated his 50th birthday in 2002, receiving a giant birthday cake and an [[AARP]] card. Shades of gray were added to the hair and wrinkles were added the figure's hands and face as Big Tex continued to "age".<ref>APPLETON, ROY. "Big Tex, 50, and he's still a hunk - No loose-fitting jeans here, but there is that AARP membership." The Dallas Morning News 17 Aug. 2002, SECOND, NEWS: 1A. NewsBank. Web. 19 Oct. 2012.</ref> In 2012 the State Fair of Texas celebrated Big Tex's 60th birthday.
==Destruction and recreation== [[File:Big Tex fire.2 retouched.jpg|thumbnail|right|Big Tex as seen during the fire on 19 October 2012]] On the morning of October 19, 2012 (the final weekend of the 2012 State Fair of Texas, and on Big Tex's 60th birthday) a fire started inside the framework of Big Tex. The figure's clothing, face and hat were completely destroyed in minutes as onlookers watched. An official investigation determined that the fire started in an electrical panel (fixed wiring) under the attraction's right boot. This panel was believed to have powered the air compressor that kept the clothing of the statue 'inflated'.<ref>{{cite web|title=Blaze began in Tex's Right Boot, State Fair official says|url=http://www.wfaa.com/news/local/Fire-leaves-Big-Tex-a-skeletal-frame-174951021.html|accessdate=5 October 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131012020522/http://www.wfaa.com/news/local/Fire-leaves-Big-Tex-a-skeletal-frame-174951021.html|archivedate=12 October 2013|df=}}</ref>
News of the fire received national attention, and fair officials committed to rebuilding Big Tex "bigger and better" in time for the 2013 fair.
Working under secrecy, a new Big Tex was created during 2013 by SRO Associates and Texas Scenic Co. at a cost of $500,000.<ref name="dallasnews.com"/> The recreated statue weighs {{convert|19,000|lb|kg|1}} more than the previous version, bringing him to {{convert|25,000|lb|kg|1}}. This allows Big Tex to withstand {{convert|100|mph|kph|1}} winds without needing support wires as in previous versions. The height was increased by {{convert|1|yd|cm|1}} to {{convert|55|ft|m|1}} tall.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nbcdfw.com/news/local/Big-Tex-Makes-His-Debut-One-Day-Early--225380402.html|title=Big Tex Makes His Debut One Day Early|work=NBC 5 Dallas-Fort Worth|accessdate=21 July 2015}}</ref> Big Tex Circle, the location during the State Fair of Texas, was also enlarged and reinforced for the larger statue.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nbcdfw.com/entertainment/the-scene/Big-Tex-Circle-Plans-Receive-Praise-in-City-Review-197890601.html|title=Big Tex Circle Plans Receive Praise|work=NBC 5 Dallas-Fort Worth|accessdate=21 July 2015}}</ref>
== Clothing == Big Tex generally receives a new shirt and jeans every 3 seasons, currently designed and fabricated by the Williamson-Dickie Manufacturing Company. His clothing will next be replaced in 2019.
Prior to 2013, Big Tex wore size 70 boots, a 75-gallon hat, a size 100 180/181 shirt made from nylon awning fabric and 284W/185L XXXXXL pair of Dickies jeans. The pants alone required {{convert|72|yd|m}} of [[denim]] and weigh in at {{convert|65|lb|kg}}. Over the years the outfit was accessorized with other articles associated with that year's State Fair of Texas theme. Big Tex has suffered a few garment mishaps over the years. In 1961, Hurricane Carla's winds tore his clothes. In 1970, his huge shirt was stolen from a pickup truck and received much publicity.<ref name="BigTex_a" />
The recreated structure for Big Tex that appeared in 2013 required new clothing and larger sizes. The new Dickie shirt features a 14-foot collar, 23 foot sleeves and weighs {{convert|130|lb|kg}}. The shirt is made from {{convert|150|yd|m}} of awning material. The new Dickie jeans features a 27-foot waist, 22 foot inseam and weighs {{convert|100|lb|kg}}. The jeans are made from {{convert|100|yd|m}} of denim material.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.storeassured.com/big-tex-infographic/ |title=Vital Stats of Big Tex |author=Blair Valk |date=29 October 2013 |work=storeassured.com |publisher=Assured Self Storage |accessdate=29 October 2013}}</ref>
==Voices of Big Tex== Big Tex welcomes fairgoers with his friendly drawl of "Hoooowdeeee, fooolllllks!" and makes regular announcements throughout the duration of the State Fair of Texas. His booming voice has been played by only a few men over six decades, who perform every day of the fair from a booth known as the "doghouse".
[[File:Centennial Liquor Sign.jpeg|thumb|Centennial Liquor sign in Dallas, Texas referencing Big Tex]]
Al Jones, a disc jockey for WRR FM 101.1, was the first voice of Big Tex. Al spoke for Big Tex for three years.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ci.dallas.tx.us/cso/archives/Exhibits/WRR/WRRdjs.htm |title=Famous WRR Disc Jockeys |author= |date= |work= |publisher=dallascityhall.com |accessdate=26 October 2012}}</ref> Radio announcer Jim Lowe, the most well-known voice of Big Tex, performed for 39 continuous years until 1998. Dan Alexander stepped up for the next two years. In 2001 a statewide competition and contest, held live at the [[Cotton Bowl (stadium)|Cotton Bowl]], announced [[Sonny Ray Stolz]] as the next voice of Big Tex. But after only one season Sonny decided not to continue due to what he considered unprofessional treatment by Fair officials and the Fair brought in runner-up Bill Bragg in 2002.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.yesterdayusa.com/bigtex/ |title=Psst! There's a new voice for Big Tex |author=Flick, David |date=26 January 2002 |publisher=The Dallas Morning News |accessdate=26 October 2012}}</ref> After the 2012 State Fair, the Fair chose not to renew Bill Bragg's contract and instead hired Dan Alexander for Big Tex, who is believed to be the new voice of Big Tex, whose contract was renewed.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.yesterdayusa.com/bigtex/ |title=Big Tex's New Voice Chosen|author=David Flick |date=23 September 2013 |publisher=NBC 5 Dallas Fort Worth|accessdate=12 January 2015}}</ref>
The voice of the 1955 Big Tex can be heard on the recording of NBC's live Wide Wide World which includes multiple segments at the State Fair.<ref>{{cite web|website=YouTube|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=37qiS76m9w0&t=3m49s|title=Big Tex Live at 1955’s State Fair}}</ref>
==Depictions== * The State Fair of Texas uses Big Tex in all marketing material, including the fair's website domain name (www.bigtex.com). * The 1962 film ''[[State Fair (1962 film)|State Fair]]'' was shot on location at the [[State Fair of Texas]], and features shots of Big Tex and the fairgrounds. * Big Tex is featured on the cover of the 1983 comic "The Uncanny X-Men at the State Fair of Texas".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://comicbookliteracy.blogspot.com/2010/04/my-first-comic-book.html|title=The Comic Book Literacy Documentary Blog: My First Comic Book|author=Todd Kent|work=comicbookliteracy.blogspot.com|accessdate=21 July 2015}}</ref> * In an episode of the FOX-TV [[animated series]] of ''[[King of the Hill]]'', Big Tex is the focus of the 8th Season episode titled "[[Girl, You'll Be a Giant Soon]]" which first aired April 25, 2004. In the episode, [[Hank Hill]] is upset that the [[State Fair of Texas]] will not allow [[propane]] [[Barbecue|Bar-B-Que]] [[Grill (cooking)|grills]] to be used. [[Luanne Platter]], Hill's niece, decides to protest this by climbing inside Big Tex and staging a [[sit-in]] protest. * Big Tex makes another appearance in ''King of the Hill'' in the episode "[[How to Fire a Rifle Without Really Trying]]", but he just says "Howdy." * In 2005, the State Fair of Texas created the Big Tex Choice Awards, an annual food competition between vendors of the fair. The trophy merges the [[Academy Award]]'s Oscar body with an oversized Big Tex head. * The name and logo for local/underground record label Burning Texan Records was inspired by the 2012 fire. * The album cover for Horror Cult's ''The Texorcist'' depicts Big Tex on fire. * The image of Big Tex and the statue's iconic stance is commonly used in regional advertising campaigns. * Big Tex image was feature prominently on a tour promotion poster of the famous Japanese J-Pop group of "[[Puffy AmiYumi]]" on their 3 city April, 2017 USA "Not Lazy Concert Tour" of which the city of Dallas, Texas was their final stop.
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== {{Commons category|Big Tex}} * [http://www.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~txnavarr/towns/kerens/santa_big_tex/index.htm Photos of "Big Tex" as Santa Claus] * "Big Tex's History". [https://web.archive.org/web/20121022170914/http://www.bigtex.com/sft/AboutUs/BigTex.asp Official Web Site of the State Fair of Texas]. * "Big Tex". [https://web.archive.org/web/20050404070154/http://www.texastwisted.com/attr/bigtex/ Texas Twisted]. Retrieved Apr. 11, 2005.
{{Portalbar|Dallas-Fort Worth|Texas}}

revision.comment: [[Wikipedia:Bots/Requests for approval/PrimeBOT 29|Task 29]] - removal of deprecated parameters from [[Template:infobox person]] (+ genfixes)
revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Captain Gallagher | image = | imagesize = | caption = | birth_date = ? | birth_place = [[Bonniconlon]], [[County Mayo, Ireland]] | death_date = 1818 | death_place = [[Castlebar]], [[County Mayo, Ireland]] | occupation = highwayman, rapparee | nationality = Irish | other_names = | known_for = He was one of the Irish Rapparees (Guerrillas) of Northern Ireland | movement = | debut_works = | signature = | website = | footnotes = }}
'''Captain Gallagher''' (died 1818) was an Irish highwayman who, as one of the later [[Irish Rapparees]] (guerrillas), led a bandit group in the hills of the Irish countryside, armed with a [[blunderbuss]], of the day, during the late 18th and early 19th century.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.stand-and-deliver.org.uk/highwaymen/gallagher.htm |title=The Irish Highwayman" as told in "Tales from the West of Ireland" by Sean Henry}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://archiver.rootsweb.ancestry.com/th/read/IRELAND/2001-01/0978997840 |title=Subject: [IRELAND] Tales from the West of Ireland}}</ref>
Born in [[Bonniconlon]], [[County Mayo]] he lived with his aunt in [[Derryronane, Swinford]] for much of his early life and raised near the woods of [[Barnalyra]]. As he reached early adulthood, he and group of others began raiding [[mail coaches]] as well as wealthy landowners and travelers throughout eastern Mayo and parts of southern [[County Sligo]] and western [[County Roscommon]].
His attacks on landowners were especially widely known and, in one reported incident, Gallagher and his men raided the home of an extremely unpopular landlord in [[Killasser]] and forced him to eat half a dozen [[eviction]] notices he had recently drawn up for nearly half a dozen [[tenant farmer]]s before escaping with silver and other valuables.
Although successfully evading British patrols for some time, he was finally apprehended by authorities in the parish of [[Coolcarney]] (or possibly [[Attymass]]) near the foothills of the [[Ox Mountains]] while recovering from an illness at a friend's home during Christmas.
He had been informed on by a neighbor whom Gallagher had formerly helped after sending a message of Gallagher's whereabouts to the British commanding officer at [[Foxford]]. Immediately sending for reinforcements from [[Ballina, County Mayo|Ballina]], [[Castlebar]] and [[Swinford]], a force of 200 [[Red coat (British army)|redcoats]] were sent after Gallagher and, upon their arrival, proceeded to surround the home where the highwayman had been staying. Gallagher, by then in poor health and not wishing to endanger his host or his family, surrendered to the British. Taken back to Foxford, he was tried and convicted before being taken to [[Castlebar]] where he was executed.
Shortly before his execution, he had claimed to the British commanding officer that his treasure had been hidden under a rock in the woods of Barnalyra. After Gallagher's execution, the officer quickly led several cavalryman to Barnalyra who discovered there were thousands of rocks in the wood, upon a long search of all the rocks within the area, they reportedly only recovered a jewel [[hilt]]ed sword. It has been speculated that Gallagher may have been hoping to lead them to the site in the hopes his men would be able to rescue him from their hideout near the Derryronane-Curryane border although the treasure, if he owned more than the sword, was never recovered.
==See also== [[Captain Rock]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.stand-and-deliver.org.uk/highwaymen/gallagher.htm Stand and Deliver! - Captain Gallagher]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Gallagher, Captain}} [[Category:Year of birth missing]] [[Category:1818 deaths]] [[Category:Highwaymen]] [[Category:Irish outlaws]] [[Category:19th-century executions by the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Executed Irish people]] [[Category:People executed for robbery]] [[Category:People executed by Ireland by hanging]] [[Category:People from County Mayo]]
{{Ireland-bio-stub}} {{crime-bio-stub}}

revision.text:
'''Charles William Frédéric Dumas''' (1721–1796) was a [[man of letters]] living in the [[Dutch Republic]] who served as an American diplomat during the [[American Revolution]].
He was born in German [[Ansbach]] to [[France|French]] parents, apparently lived in [[Switzerland]] for a time, and moved to the Netherlands around 1750.<ref>*Purcell, L. Edward. ''Who Was Who in the American Revolution''. New York: Facts on File, 1993. {{ISBN|0-8160-2107-4}}</ref> He befriended [[Benjamin Franklin]] when the latter was in Holland at the beginning of the American Revolution, and when Franklin chaired the [[Committee of correspondence]], they employed Dumas as a secret agent to aid American interests in Europe. When [[John Adams]] became minister plenipotentiary to Holland, Dumas acted as his secretary and translator. When Adams went to [[Paris]], Dumas acted as chargé d'affaires ad interim from the United States. Dumas died soon after 1794.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=2y-W-_4gIM8C&printsec=frontcover&dq=editions:0_Y6oxjHcoqbcZ0uV7i6r_#PPA603,M1 Wharton, Francis (editor) "The revolutionary correspondence of the United States." Volume 1, 1889. Government Printing Office, Washington D.C.diplomatic pages 603-604.Retrieved December 25, 2008]</ref>
In 1775, Dumas devised the first diplomatic [[cipher]] used by the Continental Congress and Benjamin Franklin for secret correspondence with agents in Europe. It was a substitution code based on a prose passage of 682 characters, so that a given character could be replaced by more than one number.<ref>[https://www.cia.gov/library/center-for-the-study-of-intelligence/csi-publications/books-and-monographs/intelligence/intelltech.html "Codes and ciphers," in "Intelligence techniques," Central Intelligence Agency Retrieved December 25, 2008]</ref>
Dumas planted stories favorable to the United States in the Gazette de Leide [[Leyden, Holland]], with the goal of gaining a good credit rating for the United States in financial markets.<ref>Knott, Stephen F., "Secret and sanctioned, covert operations and the American Presidency," Oxford University Press, 1996, page 21. {{ISBN|0-19-510098-0}} {{ISBN|978-0-19-510098-3}}. Retrieved December 25, 2008.</ref>
In 1776, Dumas contacted officials in Holland, Spain and France seeking trade in badly needed materials for the United States. This led to beneficial trade during the revolution.<ref>[http://www.earlyamerica.com/review/2002_summer_fall/foreign_policy.htm Hartsoe, Kenneth D., Commerce and diplomacy- the first year of American foreign policy 1775-1776. Retrieved December 25, 2008]</ref> He was elected a Foreign Honorary Member of the [[American Academy of Arts and Sciences]] in 1789.<ref name=AAAS>{{cite web|title=Book of Members, 1780–2010: Chapter D|url=http://www.amacad.org/publications/BookofMembers/ChapterD.pdf|publisher=American Academy of Arts and Sciences|accessdate=28 July 2014}}</ref>
==References== <references/>
{{DEFAULTSORT:Dumas, Charles William Frederick}} [[Category:1721 births]] [[Category:1796 deaths]] [[Category:People of the American Revolution]] [[Category:Fellows of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences]] [[Category:Ambassadors of the United States to the Netherlands]]

revision.comment: I have condensed the previous description, which made multiple and confusing references to the Santa Monica Museum of Art. I replaced language that suggested that the Santa Monica Museum of Art had closed permanently with language that conveys the fact that it changed its location and name. I also added specific years to Longhauser's tenure at the Moore College of Art and Design instead of referencing "seventeen years".
revision.text:
{{Infobox person | honorific_prefix = | name = Elsa Longhauser | honorific_suffix = | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | pronunciation = | birth_name = | birth_date = | birth_place = | baptised = | disappeared_date = | disappeared_place = | disappeared_status = | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | body_discovered = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | burial_place = | burial_coordinates = | monuments = | residence = | nationality = | other_names = | ethnicity = | citizenship = American | education = | alma_mater = Antioch College, University of Pennsylvania | occupation = museum director | years_active = | era = | employer = Institute of Contemporary Art, Los Angeles (ICA LA) | organization = Santa Monica Museum of Art | agent = | known_for = | notable_works = | style = | home_town = | salary = | spouse = Norman Weiner,
William Longhauser | partner = | children = | parents = | mother = | father = | relatives = | callsign = | awards = | website = | module = | module2 = | module3 = | module4 = | module5 = | module6 = | signature = | signature_size = | signature_alt = | footnotes = }} '''Elsa Longhauser''' is the founding executive director of the [[Institute of Contemporary Art, Los Angeles]] (ICA LA), formerly the [[Santa Monica Museum of Art]] (SMMoA),{{cite web|title=Santa Monica Museum of Art: Staff and Board|url=http://smmoa.org/about/staff-board/|website=Santa Monica Museum of Art|accessdate=6 March 2016}} where Longhauser served as director from 2000 until the museum ended operations in [[Bergamot Station]] in 2015.{{cite news|last1=Cheng|first1=Scarlet|title=For 10 years, Elsa Longhauser has put her own imprint on the Santa Monica Museum of Art|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2011/jan/09/entertainment/la-ca-smmoa-20110109|accessdate=6 March 2016|agency=Los Angeles Times|date=January 9, 2011}} From 1983 until 2000, Longhauser served as director of the gallery at the [[Moore College of Art and Design]] in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania.{{cite web|last1=Sozanski|first1=Edward|title=Moore College's Gallery Director Leaving|url=http://articles.philly.com/2000-03-30/living/25604858_1_moore-international-discovery-series-art-galleries-adolf-wolfli|website=Philly.com|publisher=Philadelphia Media Network, LLC|accessdate=6 March 2016|date=March 30, 2000}} ==Early life and education== Longhauser is from [[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania]]. She attended [[Antioch College]] as a young woman. She married and had three children before completing her bachelor's degree in art history in 1971, from the [[University of Pennsylvania]].Suzanne Muchnic, [http://search.proquest.com/docview/421676090/B16DD3BD2B5E426CPQ/10 "Champion of the Overlooked: The Santa Monica Museum's New Director Hopes to Make Room for Artists Who Haven't Yet Shown Up on the Radar"] ''Los Angeles Times'' (June 18, 2000): 8. ==Career== Longhauser was director of several galleries in Philadelphia early in her career. She organized an "important show" of [[outsider art]] at the [[Philadelphia College of Art]] in 1981.Janet Tyson, [https://www.newspapers.com/clip/4552370/elsa_longhauser_credited_as_an/ "Fort Worth Museums Showcase Self-Taught Artists Who Defy Labels"] ''Kerrville Daily Times'' (November 9, 1998): 5A. via [[Newspapers.com]] {{open access}} In 1993, Longhauser continued her interest in the genre when she organized a touring show of [[Terry Fox (artist)|Terry Fox]]'s work.Christopher Knight, [http://search.proquest.com/docview/282207739/B16DD3BD2B5E426CPQ/5 "Making Magic from the Mundane: Terry Fox's Work is Spiritual with a Secular Slant"] ''Los Angeles Times'' (January 23, 1994): 86. In 1998, she was guest co-curator with [[Harald Szeemann]] at the [[Museum of American Folk Art]] for a "major traveling show" of works by self-taught American artists.Philadelphia Museum of Art, [http://www.philamuseum.org/exhibitions/1998/6.html "Self-Taught Artists of the 20th Century: An American Anthology"] (March 10, 1998-May 17, 1998).Tessa DeCarlo, [http://search.proquest.com/docview/398647247/B16DD3BD2B5E426CPQ/6 "The Gallery: Drawings Lost and Found"] ''Wall Street Journal'' (March 11, 1998): A18. Elsa Longhauser became gallery director at Moore College of Art and Design in 1983; during her tenure there, she was called an "unsung hero of the local cultural scene".Edward Sozanski, [http://articles.philly.com/1991-01-09/news/25820956_1_college-galleries-adolf-wolfli-show-art "Bringing Art from Margins to the Center; As Gallery Director at Moore College of Art and Design, Elsa Longhauser is Attracting International Attention"] ''Philly.com'' (January 9, 1991). In 2000, Longhauser left Philadelphia and became director of the Santa Monica Museum of Art. ==Personal life== Longhauser married Norman B. Weiner, a doctor, as her first husband; he died in 1977.[https://www.newspapers.com/clip/4552966/obituary_of_norman_b_weiner_1977/ "Obituary: Norman Weiner"] ''Pocono Record'' (December 5, 1977): 10. via [[Newspapers.com]] {{open access}} She remarried in 1983, to William Longhauser, a graphic artist and college professor. ==References== {{reflist}} ==Further reading== *Elsa Longhauser and Harald Szeemann, eds., ''Self-Taught Artists of the Twentieth Century: An American Anthology'' (Chronicle Books 1998). {{ISBN|9780811820998}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Longhauser, Elsa}} [[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Philadelphia]] [[Category:Museum people]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Hideaki Anno | native_name = 庵野秀明 | native_name_lang = ja | image = Godzilla Resurgence World Premiere Red Carpet- Anno Hideaki (28526527191).jpg | caption = Anno at the premiere of ''[[Shin Godzilla]]'' in 2016 | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1960|05|22}} | birth_place = [[Ube, Yamaguchi]], Japan | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | known_for = ''[[Neon Genesis Evangelion]]''
''[[Gunbuster]]''
''[[Shin Godzilla]]'' | nationality = [[Japanese people|Japanese]] | occupation = Animator, director, artist, screenwriter, actor | years_active = 1982–present | spouse = [[Moyoko Anno]] (m. 2002) | website = {{URL|khara.co.jp/hideakianno/}} }} {{Anime and manga}} {{nihongo|'''Hideaki Anno'''|庵野 秀明|Anno Hideaki|born May 22, 1960}}{{cite web|url=http://www.khara.co.jp/hideakianno/personal-biography.html|title=Personal Biography - 庵野秀明公式web|author=|date=|work=khara.co.jp|accessdate=19 July 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160614020904/http://khara.co.jp/hideakianno/personal-biography.html|archivedate=14 June 2016|df=}} is a Japanese animator, film [[film director|director]], and [[actor]]. He is best known for his part in creating the popular [[anime]] series ''[[Neon Genesis Evangelion]]''. His style has become defined by his incorporation of [[postmodernism]] and the extensive portrayal of characters' thoughts and emotions, often through unconventional scenes presenting the mental deconstruction of those characters. Anno's other directorial efforts include ''[[Kare Kano]]'' (1998), ''[[Love & Pop]]'' (1998), ''[[Shiki-Jitsu]]'' (2000), ''[[Cutie Honey (film)|Cutie Honey]]'' (2004), ''[[Re: Cutie Honey]]'' (2004), ''[[Rebuild of Evangelion]]'' (2007–), and ''[[Shin Godzilla]]'' (2016).{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2015/film/asia/hideaki-anno-and-shinji-higuchi-to-direct-tohos-godzilla-2016-1201464017/|title=Hideaki Anno and Shinji Higuchi to Direct ‘Godzilla 2016′|last=Frater|first=Patrick|work=Variety|date=March 31, 2015|accessdate=March 31, 2015}} Anime directed by Anno that have won the ''[[Animage]]'' Anime Grand Prix award have been ''[[Nadia: The Secret of Blue Water]]'' in 1990, ''[[Neon Genesis Evangelion]]'' in 1995 and 1996, and ''[[The End of Evangelion]]'' in 1997. ==Biography== ===Childhood and personal life=== Anno was born in [[Ube, Yamaguchi]]; he attended Wakō Kindergarten, Unoshima Municipal Elementary School, Fujiyama Municipal Junior High School, and Yamaguchi Prefectural Ube High School where he was noted for his interest in artwork and making short films for [[Japanese Cultural Festival]]s. Anno is an agnostic and has stated that he has found Japanese spiritualism to be closest to his beliefs.{{cite web|title=Anno's Roundtable Discussion |url=http://masterwork.animemedia.com/Evangelion/anno.html |work=Animerica vol.4, no.9 |publisher=Animerica |accessdate=9 September 2012 |date=July 6, 2002 |quote=On his religious beliefs: ANNO: "I don't belong to any kind of organized religion, so I guess I could be considered agnostic. Japanese spiritualism holds that there is kami (spirit) in everything, and that's closer to my own beliefs." |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20020606012703/http://masterwork.animemedia.com/Evangelion/anno.html |archivedate=June 6, 2002 }} Anno is also a vegetarian.{{cite web|url=http://www.tv.com/people/hideaki-anno/|title=Hideaki Anno|first=|last=TV.com|date=|work=tv.com|accessdate=19 July 2016}}{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0030417/bio|title=Hideaki Anno|author=|date=|work=imdb.com|accessdate=19 July 2016}} ===Early work=== [[File:Nausicaa god warrior.png|thumb|left|The God Warrior from ''[[Nausicaä of the Valley of the Wind (film)|Nausicaä of the Valley of the Wind]]'', which Anno animated.]] Anno began his career after attending [[Osaka University of Arts]] as an [[animator]] for the anime series ''[[The Super Dimension Fortress Macross]]'' (1982–1983).{{cite web|url=http://www.gainax.co.jp/hills/anno/bymyself-e.html |title=Official biography |publisher=[[Gainax]] |accessdate=2007-05-24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070819090939/http://www.gainax.co.jp/hills/anno/bymyself-e.html#1994 |archivedate=2007-08-19 |df= }} Wrapped up in producing the [[DAICON III and IV Opening Animations]] with his fellow students, he was eventually expelled from Osaka. Anno did not gain recognition until the release of his work on [[Hayao Miyazaki]]'s [[1984 in film|1984]] film ''[[Nausicaä of the Valley of the Wind (film)|Nausicaä of the Valley of the Wind]]''. Running short on animators, the film's production studio posted an ad in the famous Japanese animation magazine [[Animage]], announcing that they were in desperate need of more animators. Anno, in his early twenties at the time, read the ad and headed down to the film's studio, where he met with Miyazaki and showed him some of his drawings. Impressed with his ability, Miyazaki hired him to draw some of the most complicated scenes near the end of the movie,Studio Ghibli, ''The Birth of Studio Ghibli'' video, [[circa|c.]] 2003 (included on UK Nausicaä DVD) and valued his work highly.{{cite web|url=http://mdn.mainichi-msn.co.jp/features/archive/news/2006/05/20060504p2g00m0fe019000c.html |title=Evangelion Special: Genesis of a major manga |publisher=[[MSN News]] |date=25 May 2007 |accessdate=2007-05-24 |df= }}{{dead link|date=May 2017|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} Anno went on to become one of the co-founders of [[Gainax]] in December 1984. He worked as an [[animation director]] for their first feature-length film, ''[[Royal Space Force: The Wings of Honneamise]]'' (1987), and ultimately became Gainax's premiere anime director, leading the majority of the studio's projects such as ''[[Gunbuster]]'' (1988) and ''[[Nadia: The Secret of Blue Water]]'' (1990–1991).{{cite web |url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0030417/ |title=IMDB Profile |publisher=[[IMDB]] |accessdate=2007-05-24 }} However, Anno fell into a four-year [[depression (mood)|depression]] following ''Nadia'' — the series was handed down to him from [[NHK]] from an original concept by Hayao Miyazaki (of which ''[[Castle in the Sky]]'' is also partly based upon) and he was given little creative control. In 1994, the minor planet [[9081 Hideakianno]] was named after him by his old friend [[Akimasa Nakamura]].{{cite news|title=祝！小惑星「庵野秀明」が誕生しました。|url=http://www.town.kumakogen.ehime.jp/culture/astro/obs/other/mp/Anno.html|website=www.town.kumakogen.ehime.jp|accessdate=19 July 2016|language=ja|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120919044425/http://www.town.kumakogen.ehime.jp/culture/astro/obs/other/mp/Anno.html|archivedate=19 September 2012|df=}}{{cite web|title=JPL Small-Body Database Browser|url=http://ssd.jpl.nasa.gov/sbdb.cgi?sstr=9081+Hideakianno|website=ssd.jpl.nasa.gov|accessdate=19 July 2016}} ===''Neon Genesis Evangelion''=== {{main article|Neon Genesis Evangelion (anime)#Production}} Anno's next project was the anime television series {{nihongo|[[Neon Genesis Evangelion (anime)|Neon Genesis Evangelion]]|新世紀エヴァンゲリオン|Shin Seiki Evangerion}} (1995–1996), which would be touted as an influential animated series. Anno's history of [[Major depressive disorder|clinical depression]]{{cite web|url=http://culturedvultures.com/evangelion-depression-hideaki-anno-lars-von-trier-anime/|title=Evangelion, Depression and why Hideaki Anno is the Lars Von Trier of anime}} was the main source for many of the psychological elements of the series and its characters, as he wrote down on paper several of the trials and tribulations of his condition. During the show's production, Anno became disenchanted with the Japanese "[[otaku]]" lifestyle. For this and other reasons (although perhaps by design as well), ''Evangelion''{{'}}s plot became increasingly dark and psychological as the series progressed, despite being broadcast in a children's television timeslot. Anno felt that people should be exposed to the realities of life at as young an age as possible, and by the end of the series all attempts at traditional [[narrative]] logic were abandoned, with the final two episodes taking place within the main character's mind. The show did not garner high ratings in Japan at its initial time slot, but after being moved to a later, more adult-oriented venue, it gained considerable popularity. Budgeting issues at Gainax also forced Anno to replace the planned ending of ''Evangelion'' with two episodes set in the main characters' minds. After these last two episodes were aired, Anno received numerous letters and emails from fans, both congratulating him on the series and criticizing the last two episodes. Among these were [[death threat]]s{{Cite web|url=https://wiki.evageeks.org/End_of_Evangelion_Death_Threats|title=End of Evangelion Death Threats - EvaWiki - An Evangelion Wiki - EvaGeeks.org|website=wiki.evageeks.org|language=en|access-date=2018-07-04}} and letters of disappointment from fans who thought Anno had ruined the series for them. In 1997, Gainax launched a project to re-adapt ''Evangelion''{{'}}s scrapped ending into a feature-length film. Once again, budgeting issues left the film unfinished, and the completed 27 minutes of animation were included as the second act of ''[[Evangelion: Death and Rebirth]]''. Eventually, the project culminated in ''[[The End of Evangelion]]'', a three-act film that served as a finale to ''Neon Genesis Evangelion''. In September 1999, Anno appeared on the NHK TV-documentary "Welcome Back for an Extracurricular Lesson, Senpai!", answering some ''Evangelion''-related questions, including the origin of the name ''Evangelion'', and teaching children about animation production.{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/buried-treasure/2007-05-03|title=Hideaki Anno talks to kids.}} On April 15, 2015, Anno spoke about his feelings regarding Asuka and Rei. He claimed: "The truth is, I have no emotional attachment to Rei at all. In the midst of making Eva, I suddenly realized that I had forgotten her. Her very existence. For example, in episode seven, I remembered and added one shot with Rei. I had no attachment to her at all. I think that was okay, because in episode eight, she didn't appear. Not even in a single shot."http://www.crunchyroll.com/anime-news/2015/04/14-1/evangelion-creator-hideaki-anno-discusses-rei-versus-asuka ===Subsequent work=== [[File:Hideaki Anno and Ryusuke Hikawa 20141030 2.jpg|thumb|left|200px|Anno with [[Ryūsuke Hikawa]]. (October 30, 2014)]] After ''Evangelion'', Anno directed the 1998 anime series ''[[Kare Kano|Kareshi Kanojo no Jijō]]'' (''Kare Kano'' for short, also known in English as ''His and Her Circumstances''), the first [[Gainax]] television series to be directly adapted from previously-written material. During the production of ''Kare Kano'', Anno became frustrated with the restrictions placed on the show by [[TV Tokyo]] after the [[Dennō Senshi Porygon|Pokémon seizure incident]]{{cite web|title=Tokyo Travelogue February 3rd, 1999|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20031101182610/http://www.nausicaa.net/~michj/tokyo/990203.html|work=[[nausicaa.net]]}} and has not directed television anime since then. The director has also made forays into live-action films, beginning with ''[[Love & Pop]]'' (1998), a [[cinéma vérité]]-style film about [[enjo kosai]] ("compensated dating", a form of teenage [[prostitution]]) in [[Japan]], of which a major portion was shot on miniature digital cameras with constantly shifting [[aspect ratio (image)|aspect ratios]]. He won Best New Director Award at 1998 [[Yokohama Film Festival]] for the film. [[Asumi Miwa]] who played the lead role won Best New Talent award respectively. His second live-action film, ''[[Shiki-Jitsu]]'' (2000) (''"Ritual Day"'' or ''"Ceremonial Day"''), is the story of a burnt-out former animation director (played by popular [[independent film|indie]] director [[Shunji Iwai]]) who falls in love with a woman disconnected from reality. Though an experimental work like ''Love & Pop'', this film was shot using the more traditional [[2.35:1]] [[aspect ratio (image)|aspect ratio]] and has a generally more polished presentation, eschewing the [[cinéma vérité]] grittiness of Anno's first live-action film. This movie earned him Best Artistic Contribution Award at [[Tokyo International Film Festival]] and very positive reviews. Anno's third [[live-action film]] was ''[[Cutie Honey (film)|Cutie Honey]]'', based on [[Go Nagai]]'s 1973 manga and anime series. Released in the summer of 2004, this lighthearted fantasy/superhero film was a stark contrast to his earlier, more realist live-action works. Later in 2004, Anno supervised but did not direct the three-part OVA, ''[[Re: Cutie Honey]]'', instead directed by [[Hiroyuki Imaishi]] (part 1), [[Takamichi Itō]] (part 2), and Masayuki (part 3). Also released in 2004 was the movie {{nihongo|''[[Funky Forest]]''|ナイスの森|Nice no Mori}}, in which Anno makes several acting cameos: as the student in the front row of the "Home Room!" skit sitting next to Hataru, in "Who's the Director?" as an animator who feels he is being overworked, and finally in "Singles Picnic" he is among the men awaiting females who never come.{{cite web | url = http://www.nice-movie.com | title = ナイスの森 | accessdate = 2007-05-27 | publisher = Tōga | date = 27 May 2007}}{{Failed verification|date=September 2007}} On August 1, 2006, Hideaki Anno's official website was updated with job listings for key animators and production staff at a company he founded, [[Studio Khara]].{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/article.php?id=9318|title=New Hideaki Anno Project in the Works|publisher=[[Anime News Network]]}} In September 2006, it is reported by the October edition of the Japanese animation magazine ''[[Newtype]]''.{{cite web | url = http://mizuki.onmitsu.jp/warehouse/festival/10th/index.html | title = Neon genesis evangelion renewal animation movie | accessdate = 2006-09-07 | publisher = meguriaite | date = 6 September 2006 }} On September 9, 2006, GAINAX's official website confirmed that ''[[Rebuild of Evangelion]]'' was in the works. The first three movies would be an alternate retelling of the TV series (including many new scenes, settings, backgrounds, characters), and the fourth movie would be a completely new conclusion to the story. Kazuya Tsurumaki and Masayuki would direct the movies while Yoshiyuki Sadamoto would provide character designs and Ikuto Yamashita would provide mechanical designs. Shinji Higuchi would provide storyboards for the first movie. The first was launched in Summer 2007, and the second and third were planned to be launched in 2008, however, the second installment was released by itself on June 27, 2009. The third movie was to be released simultaneously with the fourth, instead, the third movie was released on November 17, 2012 and a release date for the fourth movie has yet to be announced. On February 17, 2007, Anno published an official statement{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2007-02-20/hideaki-anno-releases-statement-about-new-evangelion-movies|title=Hideaki Anno Releases Statement About New Evangelion Movies|publisher=[[Anime News Network]]}} on the Japanese Yahoo Portal for the films regarding his personal involvement and goals in their production.{{cite web |url=http://www.evangelion.co.jp/theater.html |title=Rebuild of evangelion |accessdate=2006-09-12 |publisher=Gainax |date=10 September 2006 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061005071441/http://www.evangelion.co.jp/theater.html |archivedate=5 October 2006 |df= }} In October 2007, Hideaki Anno resigned from Gainax. In 2011 Anno co-produced the Koinobori Pictures movie ''Kantoku Shikkaku'' ("Failed Director"), directed by [[Katsuyuki Hirano]] featuring [[Yumika Hayashi]].{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/khara_inc/statuses/55828859714670595|title=株式会社カラー on Twitter|author=|date=|work=twitter.com|accessdate=19 July 2016}}[https://web.archive.org/web/20110410172427/http://www.khara.co.jp/news/2011/04/000004.html ][https://web.archive.org/web/20101215045545/http://johakyu.net/archives/2010/12/2010-12-11-001074.php ]{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/interest/2011-04-06/evangelion-anno-produces-kantoku-shikkaku-film|title=Interest: Evangelion's Anno Produces Kantoku Shikkaku Film|publisher=Anime News Network}}{{cite web|url=http://www.cinematoday.jp/page/N0030959|title=『エヴァ』庵野秀明の独占コメント掲載　実写映画初プロデュース作品は伝説の女優・林由美香を元恋人・平野勝之のカメラが追ったドキュメンタリー！（1/3）|author=|date=|work=cinematoday.jp|accessdate=19 July 2016}} In 2012, Anno was the curator of an exhibit entitled ''Tokusatsu- Special Effects Museum-Craftsmanship of Showa and Heisei Eras Seen Through Miniatures'', held at the [[Museum of Contemporary Art Tokyo]], featuring actual props and suits from many of Japan's [[tokusatsu]] films and TV shows. Anno also produced a short live-action film for the exhibit, entitled ''A Giant Warrior Descends on Tokyo'', featuring the Giant Warrior-God from Studio Ghibli’s animated film [[Nausicaä of the Valley of the Wind (film)|Nausicaä of the Valley of the Wind]].{{cite web|url=http://www.scifijapan.com/articles/2012/08/24/scifi-japan-tv-02-tokusatsu-museum/|title=SciFi JAPAN TV #02: Tokusatsu Museum 第２話「特撮博物館」|author=|date=24 August 2012|work=scifijapan.com|accessdate=19 July 2016}}{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=m3unlD_XIhQ|title=Tokusatsu Museum・特撮博物館 (SciFi Japan TV #02)|first=|last=CHO Japan|date=24 August 2012|website=Scifijapan.com|accessdate=19 July 2016|via=YouTube}} Anno has gone on to work with [[Hayao Miyazaki]] and [[Studio Ghibli]] on several short films which have been shown at the [[Ghibli Museum]]. He also voiced the main character [[Jiro Horikoshi]] in Miyazaki's 2013 feature film ''[[The Wind Rises]]''. Anno designed the ''[[Space Battleship Yamato#Space Battleship Yamato: 2199|Space Battleship Yamato 2199]]'' sci-fi anime television series opening sequence.{{cite news|title=Evangelion Director Hideaki Anno to Design Yamato 2199 Anime Opening |work=[[Crunchyroll]]|date=2012-02-25|url=http://www.crunchyroll.com/anime-news/2012/01/25/evangelion-director-hideaki-anno-to-design-yamato-2199-anime-opening|accessdate=2012-02-25}} In 2014, Anno and Studio Khara launched ''[[Japan Animator Expo]]'', a series of [[original net animation]]s made by various directors.{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2014-10-26/khara-dwango-launch-weekly-animator-expo-anime-shorts/.80355|title=Khara, Dwango Launch Weekly Animator Expo Anime Shorts|author=|date=|work=animenewsnetwork.com|accessdate=19 July 2016}} In March 2015, it was announced that Anno would team up with close friend and Gainax cofounder [[Shinji Higuchi]] to write and codirect ''[[Shin Godzilla]]'', the 2016 reboot of [[Toho]]'s [[Godzilla (franchise)|Godzilla franchise]].{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2015/film/asia/hideaki-anno-and-shinji-higuchi-to-direct-tohos-godzilla-2016-1201464017/|title=Hideaki Anno and Shinji Higuchi to Direct ‘Godzilla 2016’|first=Patrick|last=Frater|date=1 April 2015|work=variety.com|accessdate=19 July 2016}} ==Depictions== Anno has appeared in [[manga]] twice, both created by personal acquaintances. His wife, Moyoko Anno, wrote ''[[Insufficient Direction]]'', a chronicle of their courtship and marriage and depicting Anno's "true face" as "the founder of the [[otaku]] cult".{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2014-02-16/moyoco-anno-insufficient-direction-manga-launches-project |title=Moyoco Anno's Insufficient Direction Manga Launches Project - News |publisher=[[Anime News Network]] |date=2014-02-16 |accessdate=2016-10-22}} In 2007, a college-age version of him appeared alongside other Gainax founders [[Hiroyuki Yamaga]], [[Takami Akai]], and [[Toshio Okada]] in the [[Kazuhiko Shimamoto]] manga ''[[Aoi Honō]]''. Anno attended [[Osaka University of Arts]] with Shimamoto. ''Aoi Honō'' was adapted into a live action television drama in 2014, where Anno was played by actor [[Ken Yasuda (actor)|Ken Yasuda]].{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2014-05-24/ken-yasuda-to-play-hideaki-anno-in-aoi-hono-drama/.74869|title=Ken Yasuda to Play Hideaki Anno in Aoi Honō Drama|author=|date=|work=animenewsnetwork.com|accessdate=19 July 2016}} The 2014 animated series [[Shirobako]] has a walk-on appearance by a character named "Mitsuaki Kanno", who is an obvious caricature of Anno. ==Filmography== [[File:Hideaki Anno 20141030 2.jpg|thumb|200px|Anno participated in "The World of Hideaki Anno", [[Tokyo International Film Festival]] on October 30, 2014.]]
